style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#8212;(Continued)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">(Unaudited)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-4" continuedAt="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-5"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">The Committee Members requested that the Court order the defendants to restore all losses to the Base Trust, including approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e821-wk-Fact-A222398ABB8A5730BDD184FE639B9FF3" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_RetireeHealthCareMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">26</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, which the Committee Members allege is the Plan participants&#8217; &#8220;fair share&#8221; of the Subsidies that were allegedly misappropriated by the defendants from January 2012 through April 2015.&#160;The Committee Members also requested that the Court enjoin the defendants from alleged future violations of the Plan and ERISA with respect to treatment of the Subsidies, order the defendants to remedy all alleged ERISA-prohibited transactions and pay the Committee Members&#8217; attorneys&#8217; fees and costs.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">The Court bifurcated the case and in September 2018 the Court conducted a trial on the issue of whether the Committee Members&#8217; Complaint is barred by the applicable statute of limitations. On November 20, 2018, the Committee Members filed a motion for sanctions, alleging various discovery and trial misconduct by the defendants, and requested that the Court enter judgment in favor of the Committee Members with respect to the statute of limitations issue and award attorneys&#8217; fees to the Committee Members. On March 26, 2019, the Court granted the Committee Members&#8217; motion for sanctions and subsequently extended the statute of limitations discovery period to October 7, 2019. Briefing on the statute of limitations issue was completed in January 2020. The Court also ordered the Company to pay certain of the Committee Members' legal and other costs to file the motion for sanctions and to conduct additional discovery related to the statute of limitations issue.   </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On August 14, 2018, under the original Shy et. al. v. Navistar International Corporation, Civil Action No. 3:92-CV-333 (S.D. Ohio 1992), the Company filed a motion to schedule a status hearing to request an in-person hearing to discuss the possibility of a global resolution of various disputes under the 1993 Settlement Agreement, including but not limited to resolving the pending Profit Sharing Complaint and Committee Members&#8217; Complaint described above. As a result, in-person hearings, an in-chambers conference and several telephone conferences were held with the Court. A hearing is scheduled for June 1, 2020. Additional hearings and/or conferences may be scheduled in the future.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Based on our assessment of the facts underlying the claims in the above actions, we are unable to provide meaningful quantification of how the final resolution of these claims may impact our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">FATMA Notice</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">International Ind&#250;stria Automotiva da Am&#233;rica do Sul Ltda. ("IIAA"), formerly known as Maxion International Motores S/A ("Maxion"), now a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company, received a notice (the &#8220;FATMA Notice&#8221;) in July&#160;2010 from the State of Santa Catarina Environmental Protection Agency ("FATMA") in Brazil.&#160;The FATMA Notice alleged that Maxion sent waste to a facility owned and operated by a company known as Natureza (the &#8220;Natureza Facility&#8221;) and that soil and groundwater contamination had occurred at the Natureza Facility.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">The FATMA Notice asserted liability against Maxion and assessed an initial penalty in the amount of R</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e843-wk-Fact-5F820311780E51D190FA4451689F3DF9" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2010Q3QTD_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_FatmaNoticeTrialMember_nav_LossContingencyByTypeOfPossibleLossAxis_nav_PenaltiesMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember" unitRef="brl" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">2</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> (the equivalent of approximately less than US</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e847-wk-Fact-2A8C1EB35B0D5E34BF5422B0DFC64157" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_FatmaNoticeTrialMember_nav_LossContingencyByTypeOfPossibleLossAxis_nav_PenaltiesMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> as of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">January 31, 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">), which is not final or due until all administrative appeals are exhausted.&#160;Maxion was one of numerous companies that received similar notices.&#160;IIAA filed an administrative defense in August 2010 and has not yet received a decision following that filing. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In addition to the matter described above, there is a suit pending in the federal court of Brazil in which the federal district attorney has sued (a) FATMA, for claims related to FATMA&#8217;s actions in connection with licensing and inspection procedures related to the Natureza Facility, and (b) Selamix, as the current owner of the Natureza Facility. In this federal suit, Selamix was found liable for the contamination at the Natureza Facility due to it being the successor owner of the facility. However, the federal court&#8217;s decision does not prohibit Selamix from seeking to recover its damages from third parties that contributed to the contamination at the Natureza Facility.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In January 2018, the district attorney of the State of Santa Catarina (the "SC District Attorney"), local and state authorities, Selamix, IIAA and the 14 other companies (together, the "Companies") that are alleged to have significantly contributed to the contamination met to discuss the matter. In March 2018, Selamix informed the SC District Attorney that it would voluntarily conduct a preliminary environmental study at the Natureza Facility in an attempt to determine and allocate the liability for the contamination pursuant to an agreement with the Companies after the study is completed. The SC District Attorney agreed to suspend further inquiry into the matter until Selamix&#8217;s study had been completed.</span></div></ix:continuation><div><br/></div><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> 31</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Navistar International Corporation and Subsidiaries</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#8212;(Continued)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">(Unaudited)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-5" continuedAt="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-6"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In June 2018, Selamix presented its Environmental Preliminary Assessment Report to the SC District Attorney and the Companies alleged to have contributed to the contamination. Selamix also presented commercial proposals from two additional companies specializing in environmental studies to perform the next steps of the technical work. The SC District Attorney then requested a third commercial proposal. One of the commercial proposals included an Environmental Preliminary Assessment Report ("Phase 1 Study") and indicated that a Phase 2 assessment should be performed. In July 2019, the SC District Attorney requested that each of the Companies (including IIAA) inform the SC District Attorney of whether they intended to contribute to the costs of the portion of the Phase 2 assessment related to geophysical investigations to identify buried drums at the Natureza Facility.  The request did not include any information related to the potential range of the associated costs or indicate whether contributions for the cost of the other portions of the Phase 2 assessment would be sought from the Companies (including IIAA). IIAA responded to the request indicating that it would not contribute to the cost of the Phase 2 assessment related to geophysical investigations and requested a meeting with the SC District Attorney to discuss the next steps in the process.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In late February 2020, IIAA became aware that the SC District Attorney filed an action in the civil court of Santa Catarina against nine of the Companies (including IIAA), Selamix, and the Municipality of Schroeder (where the Natureza Facility is located) requesting that the defendants in the action bear all of the potential costs of the investigation needed to determine the parties responsible for the contamination and manage the remediation of the contamination at the Natureza Facility and that the defendants place funds in escrow to cover such costs. Prior to ruling on these issues, the court has indicated that it will schedule a hearing to allow the defendants to set forth their defenses. IIAA continues to dispute the allegations in the FATMA Notice and intends to continue to vigorously defend itself.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Sao Paulo Groundwater Notice</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In March 2014, IIAA, along with other nearby companies, received from the Sao Paulo District Attorney (the "District Attorney") a notice and proposed Consent Agreement relating to alleged neighborhood-wide groundwater contamination at or around its Sao Paulo manufacturing facility. The proposed Consent Agreement sought certain groundwater investigations and other technical relief and proposed sanctions in the amount of R</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e874-wk-Fact-60A62240BBFD55D1B19B1E2BB04353E7" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="D2014Q2SD_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_SaoPauloGroundwaterNoticeMember_nav_LossContingencyByTypeOfPossibleLossAxis_nav_SanctionsMember" unitRef="brl" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">3</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> (the equivalent of approximately less than US</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e878-wk-Fact-2C81DE40B3705389AC15D3389E7C5B83" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_SaoPauloGroundwaterNoticeMember_nav_LossContingencyByTypeOfPossibleLossAxis_nav_SanctionsMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> as of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">January 31, 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">). In November 2014, IIAA extended a settlement offer which was never accepted, rejected or countered by the District Attorney. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On August 31, 2016, the District Attorney filed civil actions against IIAA and other companies in the Central Forum of the capital of the State of Sao Paulo seeking soil and groundwater investigation and remediation, together with monetary payment in an unspecified amount. IIAA filed its defense to the civil action on January 26, 2017, alleging that IIAA had made all necessary investigations and had taken remedial measures to address the contamination and that Companhia Ambiental do Estado de Sao Paulo, the environmental agency of Sao Paulo State, had agreed to the remedial measures taken by IIAA.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">A new district attorney (the &#8220;New District Attorney&#8221;) assumed responsibility for the case in February 2018. The New District Attorney indicated that it would like the companies involved to try to reach a settlement agreement as to the remediation efforts to be taken after having discussions and negotiations with the New District Attorney&#8217;s technical experts. On September 10, 2019, the judge granted the New District Attorney's request to require answers to inquiries related to the case from the Department of Water and Electric Energy ("DAEE") and Sao Paulo State Sewage Company ("SABESP"). DAEE and SABESP responded to the requests and the parties are currently reviewing the information provided.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">There are no current demands or offers outstanding.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">MaxxForce Engine EGR Warranty Litigation</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On June 24, 2014, N&amp;C Transportation Ltd. ("N&amp;C") filed a putative class action lawsuit against NIC, NI, Navistar Canada Inc., and Harbour International Trucks in Canada in the Supreme Court of British Columbia (the "N&amp;C Action"). Subsequently, seven additional, similar putative class action lawsuits have been filed in various courts in Canada, including Alberta, Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec (together with the N&amp;C Action, the "Canadian Actions").</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On November 16, 2016, the Supreme Court of British Columbia certified a Canada-wide class comprised of persons who purchased heavy-duty trucks equipped with Advanced EGR MaxxForce 11, MaxxForce 13, and MaxxForce 15 engines designed to meet 2010 EPA regulations. On August 1, 2018, the appellate court affirmed the November 2016 decision and certified three additional narrow issues on whether misrepresentations were made in Navistar's advertising materials. The next step will be an attendance before the case management judge regarding the details of the notice of certification to be given to the class. No date for this attendance has been set.</span></div></ix:continuation><div><br/></div><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> 32</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Navistar International Corporation and Subsidiaries</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#8212;(Continued)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">(Unaudited)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-6" continuedAt="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-7"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On July 7, 2014, Par 4 Transport, LLC filed a putative class action lawsuit against NI in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois (the "Par 4 Action"). Subsequently, </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e908-wk-Fact-4F60E0559CF35484B882CC09F3C2D6FE" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyNewClaimsFiledNumber" contextRef="FD2014Q3QTD" unitRef="lawsuits" decimals="0" scale="0" format="ixt-sec:numwordsen">seventeen</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> additional putative class action lawsuits were filed in various United States district courts, including the Northern District of Illinois, the Eastern District of Wisconsin, the Southern District of Florida, the Middle District of Pennsylvania, the Southern District of Texas, the Western District of Kentucky, the District of Minnesota, the Northern District of Alabama, and the District of New Jersey (together with the Par 4 Action, the "U.S. Actions"). Some of the U.S. Actions named both NIC and NI, and alleged matters substantially similar to the Canadian Actions. More specifically, one or more of the Canadian Actions and the U.S. Actions (collectively, the "EGR Class Actions") seek to certify a class of persons or entities in Canada or the United States who purchased and/or leased a ProStar or other Navistar vehicle equipped with a model year 2008-2013 MaxxForce Advanced EGR engine.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In substance, the EGR Class Actions allege that the MaxxForce Advanced EGR engines are defective and that the Company and NI failed to disclose and correct the alleged defect. The EGR Class Actions assert claims based on theories of contract, breach of warranty, consumer fraud, unfair competition, misrepresentation and negligence. The EGR Class Actions seek relief in the form of monetary damages, punitive damages, declaratory relief, interest, fees, and costs.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In December 2014, the United States Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (the "MDL Panel") issued an order consolidating before Judge Joan B. Gottschall of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois all of the U.S. Actions, as well as certain non-class action MaxxForce Advanced EGR engine lawsuits that were pending on October 3, 2014 (the "MDL Action").</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Non-class federal lawsuits presenting pre-trial issues similar to the MDL Action continue to be transferred to the MDL Action.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On May 11, 2015, lead counsel for the plaintiffs in the MDL Action filed a consolidated complaint, which was subsequently amended multiple times.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In May 2019, the parties completed negotiation of a settlement agreement (the "Settlement Agreement") to resolve the U.S. Actions. The plaintiffs submitted the Settlement Agreement to the court for preliminary approval on May 28, 2019. The Settlement Agreement class consists of entities and natural persons who owned or leased a 2011-2014 model year vehicle equipped with a MaxxForce 11 or 13 liter engine certified to meet EPA 2010 emissions standards without selective catalytic reduction technology, provided that vehicle was purchased or leased in the U.S.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Among other things, the Settlement Agreement requires that (1) the parties establish a non-reversionary common fund consisting of cash (the &#8220;Cash Fund&#8221;) and rebates (the &#8220;Rebate Fund&#8221;) with a total value of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e930-wk-Fact-A5883A91059855E2A621972EA0CFD980" name="nav:CommonFundBalance" contextRef="FI2019Q3_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">135</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> (the &#8220;Settlement Fund&#8221;); (2) NIC and NI contribute </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e934-wk-Fact-C08BB213892D542CA52B5812E5EC42E4" name="nav:CommonFundContribution" contextRef="FI2019Q3_nav_ContributionTypeAxis_us-gaap_CashMember_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">85</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> to the Cash Fund, which will be used to pay all settlement fees and expenses, service awards, attorneys&#8217; fees and costs, and cash payments to members of the settlement class; (3) NI commit to make available rebates with a face value in the aggregate of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e938-wk-Fact-9DFC81CE93F4508485195B0CEFC59F10" name="nav:CommonFundContribution" contextRef="FI2019Q3_nav_ContributionTypeAxis_nav_RebateMember_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">50</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> to the Rebate Fund; and (4) the settlement class release NIC and NI and their affiliates from all claims and potential claims arising from or related to the allegations in the U. S. Actions, except for claims for personal injury or damage to third-party property.  The Settlement Agreement further provides that dollars or value remaining in either the Cash Fund or the Rebate Fund after claims are processed will be used to pay approved claims from the other fund if the other fund is oversubscribed (the &#8220;Waterfall&#8221;).  Any Waterfall from the Rebate Fund to the Cash Fund is capped at </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e942-wk-Fact-BABD94CA523D5076B171610A8A16A80B" name="nav:CommonFundAllocationBetweenContributionTypes" contextRef="FI2019Q3_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MaximumMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">35</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">.  Finally, the Settlement Agreement states that NIC and NI deny all claims in the U.S. Actions, deny wrongdoing, liability or damage of any kind, and deny that NIC and NI acted improperly or wrongfully in any way. On February 3, 2020, NIC and NI funded $85 million to the Cash Fund.&#160;</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On June 12, 2019, the court preliminarily approved the settlement. Members of the class were provided notice of the Settlement Agreement and an opportunity to object or opt out. Any members of the class who opted out will not receive any benefit from the Settlement Agreement or be bound by it. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Four class members filed a consolidated objection to the Settlement Agreement on October 10, 2019. On January 3, 2020, the court entered an order rejecting the objection and finding the settlement to be "fair, reasonable, and adequate." The court also granted the motion of lead counsel for the class plaintiffs for approval of an award of attorneys' fees and costs. On January 21, 2020, the court entered an Order Granting Final Approval of Class Action Settlement, Award of Attorneys' Fees and Costs and Final Order and Judgment. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">There are also non-class action MaxxForce Advanced EGR engine lawsuits filed against the Company in various state courts. A number of non-class action lawsuits have been resolved in favor of the Company prior to trial or settled for immaterial amounts. Several cases have been resolved at trial with varying results. Several other state court non-class actions are pending at this time. One of the non-class action lawsuits ("Milan"), alleging violations of the Tennessee Consumer Protection Act and fraud and involving approximately 235 trucks, was tried in Tennessee state court in August 2017, and resulted in a jury verdict of approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e956-wk-Fact-0EFFE2FAF4DA5A088E41C1A49F0C5284" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2017Q4QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">31</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> against the Company, including </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e960-wk-Fact-1D00B506F32554EFAB12557B0DCD202A" name="nav:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValuePunitiveDamages" contextRef="FD2017Q4QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">20</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in punitive damages. </span></div></ix:continuation><div><br/></div><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> 33</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Navistar International Corporation and Subsidiaries</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#8212;(Continued)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">(Unaudited)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-7" continuedAt="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-8"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In the third quarter of 2017, we recorded </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e967-wk-Fact-A3F17401BD92543F80AFEB60E1B9FF43" name="us-gaap:SellingGeneralAndAdministrativeExpense" contextRef="FD2019Q1QTD_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">31</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> of charges in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">SG&amp;A expenses</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in our</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;"> Consolidated Statements of Operations</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On August 14, 2019, a three-judge panel of the Tennessee Court of Appeals issued a unanimous opinion reversing the </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e983-wk-Fact-F9917544C18153C8B98174BBE9B74718" name="us-gaap:SellingGeneralAndAdministrativeExpense" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">31</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> judgment and </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e987-wk-Fact-231DE57A26615D8E83936B39365E3DED" name="us-gaap:LegalFees" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> of fees and costs previously awarded to the Milan plaintiffs following an appeal filed by the Company in January 2018 challenging the jury verdict. In addition, the Tennessee Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court&#8217;s judgment for Navistar on the Milan plaintiffs' warranty claims. On October 11, 2019, the Milan plaintiffs filed an application for permission to appeal this ruling to the Tennessee Supreme Court. On January 16, 2020, the Tennessee Supreme Court granted permission to appeal.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Based on our assessment of the facts underlying the claims in the above actions, the Company has recorded a charge in the Company&#8217;s fiscal second quarter ended April 30, 2019 in the amount of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e994-wk-Fact-36AA9E20D4785D18AA77B10FFC0EE70E" name="us-gaap:LitigationSettlementAmountAwardedToOtherParty" contextRef="D2019Q2_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">159</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> as a reserve for its expected obligations under the Settlement Agreement as well as for current period liabilities and potential future settlements with respect to certain other MaxxForce Advanced EGR engine lawsuits that are not included in the Settlement Agreement. In addition, the Company has released a liability of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e998-wk-Fact-196EB237D730EDC7EB159D111BE19277" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyAccrualCarryingValuePeriodIncreaseDecrease" contextRef="D2019Q2_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_MaxxForceEngineEGRWarrantyLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" sign="-" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">32</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, related to the judgment reversal in the Milan case in the third quarter ended July 31, 2019. These impacts were recorded in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">SG&amp;A expenses</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in our</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;"> Consolidated Statements of Operations</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">. Other than the aforementioned, we are unable to provide further meaningful quantification of how the final resolution of these matters may impact our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">EPA Clean Air Act Litigation</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In February 2012, NI received a Notice of Violation ("NOV") from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (the "EPA") pertaining to certain heavy-duty diesel engines which, according to the EPA, were not completely assembled by NI until calendar year 2010 and, therefore, were not covered by NI's model year 2009 certificates of conformity. The NOV concluded that NI's introduction into commerce of each of these engines violated the Federal Clean Air Act.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On July 14, 2015, the Department of Justice ("DOJ"), on behalf of the EPA, filed a lawsuit against NIC and NI in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Similar to the NOV, the lawsuit alleges that NIC and NI introduced into commerce approximately&#160;</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1019-wk-Fact-D6697767E6FB5573B13C39EC8462CD30" name="nav:NoticeOfViolationNumberOfEngines" contextRef="FI2015Q3" unitRef="engine" decimals="0" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">7,749</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#160;heavy-duty diesel engines that were not covered by model year 2009 certificates of conformity because those engines were not completely assembled until calendar year 2010, resulting in violations of the Federal Clean Air Act. On July 16, 2015, the DOJ filed an amended complaint clarifying the amount of civil penalties being sought. The lawsuit requests injunctive relief and the assessment of civil penalties of up to&#160;</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1023-wk-Fact-C4322CBB073C5376AF79C52C17552EE8" name="nav:LossContingencyCivilPenaltySoughtPerViolation" contextRef="D2015Q3Jul16" unitRef="usd" decimals="0" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">37,500</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#160;for each violation. On September 14, 2015, NIC and NI each filed an Answer and Affirmative Defenses to the Amended Complaint. We dispute the allegations in the lawsuit.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On March 1, 2017, the court entered a Memorandum Opinion and Order (i) granting a motion by the DOJ for summary judgment on the issue of liability with respect to NI, (ii) denying a motion by the DOJ for summary judgment on the issue of liability with respect to NIC, and (iii) denying a motion by NIC for summary judgment against the EPA.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On April 3, 2018, the parties jointly filed a stipulation of dismissal with prejudice for NIC only. The stipulation with prejudice has no effect on the claims made against NI. With the dismissal of NIC, the matter moved to the remedy phase with respect to NI. Fact discovery for the remedy phase is complete and at a status hearing on January 29, 2020, the court set a schedule for summary judgment filings to be completed by June 11, 2020.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Based on our assessment of the facts underlying the amended complaint above, we recorded an additional charge of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1036-wk-Fact-63776DD3B0BE086AB6089D4B275ED7B3" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyAccrualAtCarryingValue" contextRef="FI2020Q1" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">4</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the first quarter of 2020 in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">SG&amp;A expenses</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Consolidated Statements of Operations. </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Total charges and cash outlays in future periods could range from </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1048-wk-Fact-70B7B19D537958AE801CA038EBBAEC42" name="nav:LossContingencyCivilPenaltySoughtPerViolation" contextRef="D2015Q3Jul16_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_EPAMember_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MinimumMember_us-gaap_LossContingenciesByNatureOfContingencyAxis_us-gaap_DamagesFromProductDefectsMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">6</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> to </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1052-wk-Fact-C29F8BA64B9C5917B6149C07E03728D6" name="nav:LossContingencyCivilPenaltySoughtPerViolation" contextRef="D2015Q3Jul16_nav_ContingencyDisclosureRelatedToLitigationByTrialOrRulingAxis_nav_EPAMember_srt_RangeAxis_srt_MaximumMember_us-gaap_LossContingenciesByNatureOfContingencyAxis_us-gaap_DamagesFromProductDefectsMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">291</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> related to the resolution of this matter. Other than the aforementioned, we are unable to provide further meaningful quantification of how the final resolution of this matter may impact our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">California Air Resources Board Notice of Violation</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On March 28, 2019, Navistar received a notice of violation ("NOV") from the California Air Resources Board ("CARB"). In the NOV, CARB alleges that Navistar failed to disclose a running change to 1,385 engines including certain model year 2013 to 2015 N13 engines and 2014 to 2015 N9/10 engines. CARB alleges that the running change in question made modifications to the emissions control system such that the engines no longer conformed to the configuration as certified. In August 2019, the Company and CARB reached a tentative resolution of this matter for approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1062-wk-Fact-2EFE41BD2A0C5F65A3C6CC3285F31D9E" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_CARBMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">2</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, subject to agreement on formal terms.</span></div></ix:continuation><div><br/></div><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> 34</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Navistar International Corporation and Subsidiaries</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements&#8212;(Continued)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">(Unaudited)</span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:174%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><div><br/></div><ix:continuation id="TextSelection-6923EEE49C5E5B58B33A935C5FA851E9-8"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Based on our assessment of the facts underlying the claims in the above action, the Company recorded a charge in the third quarter ended July 31, 2019 in the amount of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1069-wk-Fact-DA996097A18F4BDC1BAC9D13FA7E7729" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyAccrualAtCarryingValue" contextRef="FI2019Q3_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_CARBMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">2</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> as a reserve for its expected obligations in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Engineering and product development costs</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Consolidated Statements of Operations</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">. Other than the aforementioned, we are unable to provide further meaningful quantification of how the final resolution of this matter may impact our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Navistar Defense MRAP Litigation</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In the third quarter of 2016, Navistar Defense, LLC ("NDLLC") received a subpoena from the United States Department of Defense Inspector General (the "DOD IG"). The subpoena requested documents relating to NDLLC's sale of its independent suspension systems ("ISS") for military vehicles to the government for the period from January 1, 2009 through December 31, 2010.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Beginning in June 2016, NDLLC made submissions of documents responsive to the subpoena and engaged in ongoing discussions with government representatives, including representatives from the DOD IG and the Department of Justice ("DOJ"). Such discussions included assertions that NDLLC may have overcharged the United States for the ISS components. In August 2017, NDLLC received a letter from the DOJ claiming that NDLLC made false and misleading statements during the course of price negotiations and during the Defense Contract Audit Agency audit which resulted in NDLLC overcharging the United States for the ISS components by approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1091-wk-Fact-9A6C6FBFA96A5B00B8DA30EEED9AB12B" name="nav:LossContingencyOverchargePenalty" contextRef="FD2017Q4QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">88</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> and asking for treble damages and penalties for a total demand of approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1095-wk-Fact-CF5A04ED01D75AC1814BAB0A600AA71D" name="nav:TrebleDamagesandPenalties" contextRef="FD2017Q4QTD" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">264</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">. NDLLC responded to the DOJ&#8217;s demand letter explaining its position that it has no liability in this matter, and outlining the bases for such position, and stating that NDLLC intends to vigorously defend its position.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On December 8, 2017, NDLLC received another subpoena from the DOD IG which requested documents relating to NDLLC's pricing of the Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (&#8220;MRAP&#8221;) vehicle and its sale of parts to the government for the period from January 1, 2006 through December 31, 2013. NDLLC responded to the subpoena. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On July 10, 2018, NDLLC received another subpoena from the DOD IG requesting additional custodian emails and documents related to the MRAP and ISS components. NDLLC responded to the subpoena. Additionally, in September and October 2018, the DOJ conducted interviews of certain current and former employees.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">On December 3, 2019, the DOJ filed a complaint against NDLLC in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia partially intervening in what had been a sealed False Claims Act (&#8220;FCA&#8221;) case previously filed by a relator. The relator, a former NDLLC employee, filed his initial complaint in September 2013 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The relator filed an amended complaint on November 1, 2019, alleging that NDLLC submitted false pricing support to the government in connection with </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1108-wk-Fact-B7B05478A093B6F30CEE9D41FE32459B" name="nav:NumberofMRAPContractParts" contextRef="I2020Q1Nov01" unitRef="part" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt-sec:numwordsen">three</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> MRAP contract parts or part systems - the chassis, the engine, and </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1112-wk-Fact-96F175C5EBF4147EB1599D2B7F9265EF" name="nav:NumberofComponents" contextRef="I2020Q1Nov01" unitRef="component" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">13</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> components of the 3,898 ISS kits (&#8220;Relator&#8217;s ISS Claim&#8221;). The relator alleges single damages of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1116-wk-Fact-579781FA75E6068192B99D296E91C3A1" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="D2019Q1NOV01-01_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_NavistarDefenseMRAPLitigationMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember_us-gaap_LossContingenciesByNatureOfContingencyAxis_nav_ChasisMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-8" scale="9" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.1</ix:nonFraction> billion</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> for the chassis, </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1120-wk-Fact-0E64A3769B69C3B8F9C29D3959F747F2" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="D2019Q1NOV01-01_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_NavistarDefenseMRAPLitigationMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember_us-gaap_LossContingenciesByNatureOfContingencyAxis_nav_EngineMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">36</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> for the engine, and </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1124-wk-Fact-0B3907640B42206892979D398FF07F78" name="us-gaap:LossContingencyDamagesSoughtValue" contextRef="D2019Q1NOV01-01_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_NavistarDefenseMRAPLitigationMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember_us-gaap_LossContingenciesByNatureOfContingencyAxis_nav_RelatorsISSClaimMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-6" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">119</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> for the Relator&#8217;s ISS Claim, totaling approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1129-wk-Fact-B4A04A6234874387263A9D3AAE81581D" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">1.3</ix:nonFraction> billion</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in single damages and </span><span contextRef="D2019Q1NOV01-01_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_NavistarDefenseMRAPLitigationMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember" unitRef="usd" decimals="-8" scale="9" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">3.8</ix:nonFraction> billion</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in treble damages. The DOJ&#8217;s complaint-in partial intervention alleges that NDLLC submitted false pricing support in connection with </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17550809e1137-wk-Fact-38FD4F31E877206BF7399D2D321DE175" name="nav:NumberofComponents" contextRef="I2020Q1Nov01_srt_LitigationCaseAxis_nav_NavistarDefenseMRAPLitigationMember_us-gaap_LitigationStatusAxis_us-gaap_PendingLitigationMember" unitRef="component" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">11</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> of the components of 3,803 ISS kits and seeks damages of an unspecified amount under the FCA and common law theories of mistake, unjust enrichment, and fraud. On January 10, 2020, NDLLC filed a motion to transfer venue to the Northern District of Illinois. On January 16, 2020, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia entered an order staying deadlines to respond to the complaints, pending resolution of the motion to transfer venue.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">NDLLC intends to defend itself vigorously.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">At this time, we are unable to predict the outcome of these matters, including whether a settlement will be reached, or provide meaningful quantification of how the final resolution of this matter may impact our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.</span></div></ix:continuation><div><a id="s12E9A2DEC3A557B08613EB10C8830CE5"></a></div><div font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:36px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;padding-left:12px;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#8226;</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Parts</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> segment provides customers with proprietary products needed to support the International commercial truck, IC Bus, proprietary engine lines, and export parts business, as well as our other product lines. Our Parts segment also provides a wide selection of other standard truck, trailer, and engine aftermarket parts.&#160;Also included in the Parts segment are the operating results&#160;of BDP, which manages the sourcing, merchandising, and distribution of certain service parts we sell to Ford in North America. </span></div></td></tr></table><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="padding-top:8px;font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:36px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;padding-left:12px;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#8226;</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Global Operations</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> segment primarily consists of Brazil engine operations which produce diesel engines under contract manufacturing arrangements, as well as under the MWM brand, for sale to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) in South America. </span></div></td></tr></table><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="padding-top:8px;font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt;"><tr><td style="width:36px;"></td><td></td></tr><tr><td style="vertical-align:top"><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;padding-left:12px;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#8226;</span></div></td><td style="vertical-align:top;"><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Financial Services</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> segment provides retail, wholesale, and lease financing of products sold by the Truck and Parts segments and their dealers within the U.S.&#160;and Mexico, as well as financing for wholesale accounts and selected retail accounts receivable. This segment also facilitates financing relationships in the U.S. and other countries to support our Manufacturing Operations.</span></div></td></tr></table><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Corporate contains those items that are not included in our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17561703e664-wk-Fact-1CFCA757686E51DF809393C0EF91E8D9" name="us-gaap:NumberOfReportableSegments" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD" unitRef="segments" decimals="INF" scale="0" format="ixt-sec:numwordsen">four</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> segments.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Segment Profit (Loss)</span></div><ix:nonNumeric contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD" name="us-gaap:ScheduleOfSegmentReportingInformationBySegmentTextBlock" id="TextSelection-DBAE3234DC93509E8B2E7C6244F647CA-0-wk-Fact-CB48B4A9849B503E880429F31457C38C" continuedAt="TextSelection-DBAE3234DC93509E8B2E7C6244F647CA-1" escape="true"><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">We define segment profit (loss) as net income (loss) attributable to NIC, excluding income tax benefit (expense). 2019 (the &#8220;2019 Convertible Notes&#8221;) was </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17564452e1224-wk-Fact-513BC505FD5A5D64B7AF332075B32984" equivalent to an initial conversion price of approximately </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17564452e1232-wk-Fact-F1147BB8C2F6561AB0E9B09A4BB21450" name="us-gaap:OptionIndexedToIssuersEquityStrikePrice1" contextRef="FD2020Q1QTD_us-gaap_DebtInstrumentAxis_nav_FourPointSevenFiveSeniorSubordinatedConvertibleNotesMemberMember" unitRef="usdPerShare" decimals="2" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">54.07</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> per share of common stock. The 2019 Convertible Notes had an anti-dilutive effect when calculating diluted earnings per share when our average stock price was less than </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span>$<ix:nonFraction id="d17564452e1236-wk-Fact-F1147BB8C2F6561AB0E9B09A4BB21450" name="us-gaap:OptionIndexedToIssuersEquityStrikePrice1" contextRef="FD2020Q1QTD_us-gaap_DebtInstrumentAxis_nav_FourPointSevenFiveSeniorSubordinatedConvertibleNotesMemberMember" unitRef="usdPerShare" decimals="2" scale="0" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">54.07</ix:nonFraction></span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">. The 2019 Convertible Notes were fully repaid upon maturity in April 2019, and none were converted into shares of our common stock.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">The computation of diluted earnings per share excludes outstanding options and other common stock equivalents in periods where inclusion of such potential common stock instruments would be anti-dilutive. For the </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">three months ended January 31, 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, no dilutive securities were included in the computation of diluted earnings per share because they would have been anti-dilutive due to the net loss attributable to NIC.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> For the </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">three months ended January 31, 2019</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, certain securities have been excluded from the computation of earnings per share, as our average stock price during the period was less than their respective exercise prices. The aggregate shares not included were </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17564452e1254-wk-Fact-D2E3917C932253DE98813BB54DE61008" name="us-gaap:AntidilutiveSecuritiesExcludedFromComputationOfEarningsPerShareAmount" contextRef="FD2020Q1YTD" unitRef="shares" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">9.9</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, comprised primarily of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><span><ix:nonFraction id="d17564452e1258-wk-Fact-406D41F1AFE553A9964396FB91E1AAA4" name="nav:SharesRelatedToConvertibleNotes" contextRef="FD2019Q1YTD_us-gaap_DebtInstrumentAxis_nav_FourPointSevenFiveSeniorSubordinatedConvertibleNotesMemberMember" unitRef="shares" decimals="-5" scale="6" format="ixt:numdotdecimal">7.6</ix:nonFraction> million</span></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> shares</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;color:#ff0000;"> </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">related to the 2019 Convertible Notes.</span></div></ix:continuation><div><a id="s0CCE0211566B595BB1F677C021C73B76"></a></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 2. &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Management&#8217;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations ("MD&amp;A") is designed to provide information that is supplemental to, and should be read together with, our consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes contained in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">October&#160;31, 2019</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">. Information in MD&amp;A is intended to assist the reader in obtaining an understanding of (i)&#160;our consolidated financial statements, (ii)&#160;the changes in certain key items within those financial statements from year-to-year, (iii)&#160;the primary factors that contributed to those changes, (iv)&#160;any changes in known trends or uncertainties from items disclosed within the MD&amp;A of our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">October&#160;31, 2019</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> that we are aware of and that may have a material effect on our future performance, and (v)&#160;how certain accounting principles affect our consolidated financial statements. In addition, MD&amp;A provides information about our business segments and how the results of those segments impact our results of operations and financial condition as a whole. Operating results for interim reporting periods are not necessarily indicative of annual operating results.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Executive Overview</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">Navistar is an international manufacturer of International&#174; brand commercial trucks, proprietary brand diesel engines, and IC Bus&#174;</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><sup style="vertical-align:top;line-height:120%;font-size:7pt"> </sup></span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">("IC") brand school and commercial buses, as well as a provider of service parts for trucks and diesel engines. Our core business is conducted in the North American truck and parts markets, where we principally participate in the U.S. and Canada school bus and Class 6 through 8 medium and heavy truck markets (our "Core" markets). We also provide retail, wholesale, and lease financing services for our trucks and parts.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">First Quarter Summary </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">During </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, we took actions to build upon our 2019 accomplishments. We are focused on our Navistar 4.0 playing to win strategy, which is based on three critical elements: driving high performing cross-functional teams, creating a sustainable longer-term performance advantage within our products and services, and identifying and focusing on key markets where we have a differentiated value to prove to our customers that we are their #1 choice.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Financial Summary </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Continuing Operations Results </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">&#8212; In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, our consolidated net sales and revenues were </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$1.8 billion</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, a </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">24%</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> decrease compared to the comparable prior year period. The decrease reflects lower overall volumes from our Truck segment.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, we incurred a loss before income tax of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$37 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> compared to </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$2 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the comparable prior year period. Our gross margin decreased by </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$145 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> primarily due to the impact of lower volumes. In the first quarter of 2019, we purchased group annuity contracts for certain retired pension plan participants which resulted in pension settlement accounting charges of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$142 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">.  In the first quarter of 2019, we also recorded a gain of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$54 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> related to the sale of a majority interest in our former defense business, ND Holdings, LLC ("Navistar Defense") and a gain on sale of $5 million related to our joint venture in China with Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Bo., Ltd ("JAC").</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, we recognized an income tax benefit of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$5 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> compared to an income tax benefit of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$19 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the prior year. The decrease to income tax benefit for the first quarter is largely the result of a $38 million benefit associated with a group annuity contract purchase for certain retired pension plan participants, recorded in the first quarter of 2019. Other differences for the first quarter of 2020 include the impact of earnings, the sale of Navistar Defense in the first quarter of 2019, geographical mix, and certain discrete items. </span></div><div><br/></div><div><div style="line-height:120%;text-align:center;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> 39</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div style="line-height:120%;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div></div><hr style="page-break-after:always"></hr><div><br/></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, after income taxes, we had a net loss attributable to Navistar International Corporation ("NIC") of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$36 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> or </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$0.36</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> per diluted share compared to net income of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$11 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> or </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$0.11</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> per diluted share in the respective prior year period. </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, consolidated net income attributable to NIC, before manufacturing interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization expenses (&#8220;EBITDA&#8221;) was </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$55 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> compared to </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$96 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the comparable prior year period. Excluding certain net impacts, adjusted EBITDA ("Adjusted EBITDA") in </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> was </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$59 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> compared to </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$173 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the comparable prior year period. In </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">, adjusted consolidated net income (loss) attributable to NIC, excluding certain net impacts ("Adjusted Net Income (Loss)"), was a loss of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$33 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> compared to income of </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$57 million</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> in the comparable prior year period. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, and Adjusted Net Income (Loss) are not determined in accordance with U.S. GAAP, nor are they presented as alternatives to U.S. GAAP measures. For more information regarding this non-GAAP financial information, see Non-GAAP Financial Performance Measures.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">We ended </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">the first quarter of 2020</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> with </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$1.0 billion</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> of consolidated cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities, compared to </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">$1.4 billion</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> as of October&#160;31, 2019. The decrease was primarily attributable to an increase in inventories, decreases in accounts payable, other current and postretirement liabilities, capital expenditures, and repayments under secured and revolving credit facilities and principal payments on long-term debt partially offset by decreases in accounts and finance receivables.</span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"><br/></span></div><div><a id="s66A1BF54A77454BAB67D980AE0C57148"></a></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-weight:bold;">Results of Operations </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;font-size:10pt;"><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;">The following information summarizes our </span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;">Consolidated Statements of Operations</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;"> and illustrates the key financial indicators used to assess our consolidated financial results.  </span></div><div style="line-height:120%;padding-top:8px;text-align:left;padding-left:0px;text-indent:0px;font-size:10pt;"><span ended January 31, 2019</span><span style="font-family:inherit;font-size:10pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;"> </span><div
